**The Sceptre of Might** is the [Caveman](/wiki/Caveman "Caveman") [quest artifact](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact"). It is the prize for completing the [Caveman quest](/wiki/Caveman_quest "Caveman quest"), and is [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful") for [wishing](/wiki/Wish "Wish") purposes. Its base item type is a [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Effects](#Effects)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)
  - [2.1 Average damage calculation](#Average_damage_calculation)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Messages](#Messages)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [5.3 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [7 References](#References)

## Effects

When wielded, the Sceptre confers [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance"); it has +d5 to-hit and deals double damage against monsters with a different alignment than the Sceptre. [Invoking](/wiki/Invoking "Invoking") the Sceptre toggles [conflict](/wiki/Conflict "Conflict") on or off; if the Sceptre leaves your main inventory, it will also stop causing conflict. Conflict caused by the Sceptre does not cause the usual [nutrition](/wiki/Nutrition "Nutrition") drain.

## Strategy

- *See also: [Invoke § Optimum invocation schedule](/wiki/Invoke#Optimum_invocation_schedule "Invoke")*

Thanks to its alignment-based [double damage](/wiki/Double_damage "Double damage"), the Sceptre is one of the best weapons in the game versus cross-aligned monsters, and your quest artifact is always co-aligned. Since most monsters in the game are either [neutral](/wiki/Neutral "Neutral") or [chaotic](/wiki/Chaotic "Chaotic"), for [lawful](/wiki/Lawful "Lawful") characters the Sceptre is a great weapon, comparable even with a similarly enchanted [Grayswandir](/wiki/Grayswandir "Grayswandir") against most non-silver hating monsters. However, the Sceptre is a somewhat weaker artifact for [neutral](/wiki/Neutral "Neutral") Cavepeople; this becomes particularly noticeable in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom"). [Erosion](/wiki/Erosion "Erosion")-proofing is recommended in either case, as quest artifacts are not generated damage-proof like [sacrifice gifts](/wiki/Sacrifice_gift "Sacrifice gift"); a backup source of magic resistance is also recommended, as the [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") can steal the Sceptre from you.

The magic resistance, damage bonuses and conflict toggle also make the Sceptre of Might a viable (though optional) artifact [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") for [Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight") and lawful [Priests](/wiki/Priest "Priest") that have an early one to spare.

### Average damage calculation

The average damage calculations in the following table do not include bonuses from [weapon skills](/wiki/Skill "Skill"), [strength](/wiki/Strength "Strength"), or from using a [blessed](/wiki/Blessed "Blessed") weapon against [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") or [demons](/wiki/M2_DEMON "M2 DEMON").

## History

The Sceptre of Might is introduced along with most of the other quest artifacts in [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0"); from this version to [NetHack 3.1.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.3 "NetHack 3.1.3"), its base item type was a [quarterstaff](/wiki/Quarterstaff "Quarterstaff").

In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), earlier versions and some variants based on them, the Sceptre of Might's magic resistance was conferred when carried.

## Messages

- You feel like a rabble-rouser.

  You invoked the Sceptre of Might and are now causing [conflict](/wiki/Conflict "Conflict").

- You feel the tension decrease around you.

  You invoked the Sceptre of Might (or it left your main inventory), and you are no longer causing conflict.

- You feel a surge of power, but nothing happens.

  You invoked the Sceptre, but you were already causing conflict by other means.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), The Sceptre of Might confers its magic resistance while carried, but its bonuses are significantly lowered to +3 to-hit and +5 bonus damage versus cross-aligned monsters, making it much weaker as a weapon.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) [Artifact blasts](/wiki/Artifact_blast "Artifact blast") also do far more damage at 8d10 (or 6d10 with magic resistance).

The Sceptre is still a solid artifact for its magic resistance and hunger-less conflict invoke, but is heavily outclassed in terms of damage by other artifact weapons such as the [Sword of Justice](/wiki/Sword_of_Justice "Sword of Justice") and [The Stake of Van Helsing](/wiki/The_Stake_of_Van_Helsing "The Stake of Van Helsing"); [The Crown of Saint Edward](/wiki/The_Crown_of_Saint_Edward "The Crown of Saint Edward") and the [Magic Mirror of Merlin](/wiki/Magic_Mirror_of_Merlin "Magic Mirror of Merlin") are also comparable candidates for lawful artifact sources of magic resistance.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), The Sceptre of Might is the [Priest](/wiki/Priest "Priest") quest artifact, replacing the removed [the Mitre of Holiness](/wiki/The_Mitre_of_Holiness "The Mitre of Holiness"); it confers [drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance") when wielded, and invoking it provides an [energy](/wiki/Energy "Energy") boost instead of toggling conflict. Cavemen have a new quest artifact called [Big Stick](/wiki/Big_Stick "Big Stick"), which confers magic resistance when wielded and can be invoked for conflict akin to the vanilla Sceptre.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), the Sceptre of Might has its base item type changed to a [rod](/wiki/Rod "Rod"), which is made of gemstone and deals slightly more damage against large monsters than a mace (1d8), making the Sceptre a significantly better weapon. Of note is that the Wizard of Yendor is capable of weapon attacks in EvilHack, and will use the Sceptre against you should he steal it.

## Encyclopedia entry

This mace was created aeons ago in some unknown cave, and has been passed down from generation to generation of cave dwellers. It is a very mighty mace indeed, and in addition will protect anyone who wields it from magic missile attacks. When invoked, it causes conflict in the area around it.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [artilist.h in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 331](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/artilist.h#line331 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/artilist.h")
